articleContent.title: Chord: Dominant 7th in F# (Shape: G)
articleContent.content:
# Dominant 7th Chord in F# (Shape: G)

The Dominant 7th chord in the key of F# is built on the note G#. In this particular instance, when referring to the G shape in a dominant 7th chord voicing, its root note from F# is played on the 4th fret of the D string. 

## Notes and Intervals
- G# (Root)
- D# (Major 5th)
- F# (Minor 7th)
- A# (Major 2nd)

## Genre and Musical Flavor
The Dominant 7th chord in F# (Shape: G) is commonly found in genres such as jazz, blues, and funk. It offers a bluesy and jazzy flavor to music, providing tension and leading naturally to the tonic chord in the key, creating a sense of resolution and movement in the music.

## Songs
Here are three songs that prominently feature the Dominant 7th chord in F# (Shape: G):
1. **"Still Got the Blues" by Gary Moore** - This blues classic utilizes dominant 7th chords throughout the song, including variations like the one in F#.
2. **"So What" by Miles Davis** - A jazz standard that features dominant 7th chords, including the F# shape, as part of its harmonic structure.
3. **"Superstition" by Stevie Wonder** - This funk hit uses dominant 7th chords to create its groovy and infectious sound, with the F# shape potentially making an appearance in the progression.
